awd_titl_txt: The Origin and Survival of Chemical Heterogeneities in the Earth's Mantle
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurately determining the Earth's chemical composition has been and remains one of the most fundamental challenges in Earth sciences. It has important implications not only for the long-debated question of how terrestrial planets form and evolve, but also for our understanding of the consequences of the ongoing processes on our planet. The Earth's mantle is the largest of all terrestrial reservoirs; it constitutes 83% of the Earth's volume and extends to 2900 km below its surface. The chemically and isotopically heterogeneous nature of this vast reservoir has long been established as a result of previous pioneering studies of the terrestrial rock record. Some of the heterogeneities have been argued to be primordial, reflecting initial planetary accretion/differentiation and magma ocean crystallization processes. Others were likely created as a result of a protracted, violent terrestrial accretion history, or to have resulted from later processes associated with the dynamic regime of the planet, especially crustal recycling. Despite the long-term, concerted research effort, the nature, origin, scale, and longevity of early mantle chemical and isotope heterogeneities are still not well understood. This project is aimed at filling the existing gaps in our understanding of these fundamental issues by applying a carefully chosen, comprehensive set of state-of-the-art modern analytical tools to a collection of unique 3.5 to 2.7 billion year old komatiite samples from western Australia. These samples are especially advantageous to study processes that occurred within the first 2 billion years of Earth history, before the crust formation and recycling processes, similar to those occurring today, took over as the main driver of chemical differentiation of the Earth's interior and erased all the evidence of Earth's youthful exuberance.

This research effort is aimed at constraining the origin and temporal evolution of chemical and isotopic heterogeneities in the early Earth's mantle. The primary goals are to: (1) assess the magnitude of chemical/isotopic heterogeneities recorded in the mantle sources of 3.52 to 2.69 Ga komatiites from Western Australia, (2) establish which of such fundamental early Earth processes, as late accretion, magma ocean crystallization, primordial crust extraction, and crustal recycling, were responsible for creating these heterogeneities, and (3) integrate the new short- and long-lived isotopic and trace element abundance data for these rocks with the existing data for Archean komatiite systems into models for the origin and temporal evolution of global chemical/isotope heterogeneities in the Earth's mantle. In order to achieve these goals, the team will study isotope systematics, and lithophile trace element and highly siderophile element abundances in diamond drill core samples of the 3.5 to 2.7 Ga komatiite systems using the thermal ionization mass-spectrometry and inductively-coupled plasma mass-spectrometry techniques. These komatiitic systems are from the ancient Pilbara and Yilgarn Cratons of Western Australia, and their formation spans a time interval of ca. 800 Ma of Earth history. These localities were selected in order to cover the greatest possible extent of temporal variations within spatially related Archean cratons, because the selected samples are well preserved by Archean standards and are expected to provide a window into the early terrestrial mantle, and because limited existing data indicate that these komatiite systems record very early mantle differentiation processes. The results are expected to allow us to assess the possible effects of differentiation of a primordial magma ocean, late accretion, and crustal recycling, as well as permit new constraints to be placed on the mixing times of the mantle during the first half of Earth's history.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project was aimed at constraining the origin and temporal evolution of chemical heterogeneities in the Earth's mantle during the Hadean and Archean. The primary goals of the research were to: (1) assess the magnitude of chemical and isotopic heterogeneities recorded in the mantle sources of the early Archean komatiites from Western Australia, (2) establish which of such fundamental early Earth processes, as late accretion, magma ocean crystallization, primordial crust extraction, and crustal recycling were responsible for creating them, and (3) integrate short- and long-lived isotopic and lithophile trace and highly siderophile element (HSE) abundance data for these and other well studied komatiite systems from around the globe into models for the origin and temporal evolution of global chemical heterogeneities in the Earth's mantle.

The 147Sm-143Nd and 176Lu-176Hf isotope data for a comprehensive set of samples from the ~3.53 Ga Coonterunah, ~3.34 Ga Kelly, and ~3.18 Ga Ruth Well and Regal komatiite-basalt systems yielded isochrons consistent with the emplacement ages of the stratigraphic sequences. Their calculated mantle sources evolved with long-term model 147Sm/144Nd = 0.200 to 0.214 and 176Lu/177Hf = 0.0355 to 0.0395, spanning the entire range of time-integrated Sm/Nd and Lu/Hf ratios in global komatiite-basalt systems (Figure 1).

The coupled 143Nd-176Hf isotope systematics observed in the Pilbara komatiite-basalt systems indicate that variable-degree early episodes of partial melting and melt extraction most likely account for the observed large variations in the time-integrated Sm/Nd and Lu/Hf ratios in their mantle sources, some of which were already as melt-depleted at ~3.5 Ga as the modern mid-ocean ridge basalt mantle. None of these domains had compositions similar to projections for the bulk silicate Earth (BSE).

The calculated total HSE abundances in the mantle sources of the komatiites range from ~30% in the Coonterunah to ~70% in the Regal system, relative to estimates for the present-day BSE (Figure 2). With few important exceptions, results from our group for global komatiites sources are consistent with increasing HSE abundances in the mantle sources of komatiites into the late Archean.

All four Pilbara komatiite-basalt systems exhibit positive μ182W values, ranging between +11.4 and +7.7. The combined μ182W - source HSE abundance data for the Pilbara komatiite-basalt systems are inversely correlated (Figure 3) and are consistent with the grainy late accretion model, whereby the final ~1% of Earth's mass was added subsequent to core formation via the accretion of several large, Pluto-mass, planetesimals.

Regression of the global μ182W - mantle source HSE abundance data permits an estimate of the W isotopic composition of the pre-late accretion BSE of +17±7 (Figure 3). This estimate overlaps with the independently determined value of +25±5 for the Moon and provides support to the notion regarding the common W isotopic composition in the Earth-Moon system and origin of the Moon from materials that isotopically equilibrated with terrestrial materials.

Regression of the available HSE abundance data for komatiite mantle sources worldwide versus time (Figure 2) also provides an estimate for the timing of complete homogenization of late accreted materials within the mantle at 2.5±0.2 Ga. This provides an estimate for an average homogenization rate of the mantle domains sampled by komatiites in the Hadean and Archean.

The support from this award made possible close collaborations with scientists from Australia, Austria, Canada, Finland, France, Germany, Russia, the UK, and the US. The PI shared his expertise in high-temperature mantle geochemistry, planetary formation, late accretion, and petrology of komatiites.

The award enabled the PI to partially support and serve as the advisor to Ph.D. student R.W. Nicklas and B.Sc. student J. Slagle (both graduated in 2019). Both Nicklas and Slagle participated in the interpretation and presentation of the results and manuscript writing. This training provided them with the skills crucial for their careers as geoscientists.

The results from this project were reported as regular and invited talks at the annual 2018, 2019, 2020, and 2021 V.M. Goldschmidt Conferences and the 2018 and 2021 AGU Fall Meetings. The PI was invited by Profs. T. Kleine and H. Becker to give lectures at the University of Muenster (2018) and Freie Universitaet Berlin (2019). These visits provided the PI with the opportunity for broader dissemination of the results and for public outreach to a diverse scientific community. The PI was also invited to give two Plenary lectures at the International Conference "Petrology and Geodynamics of Geological Processes" that was held in Irkutsk, Russia in September, 2021.

Six research and review papers have been published in peer-reviewed journals, and one manuscript is presently under review, as a result of full or partial support from this grant. As a result of the PI's NSF-funded activities, in 2020 he received the University of Maryland Provost's Excellence Award for "Outstanding contributions and accomplishments in research".
